citation.article-title: Transfer of Pseudomonas aminovorans (den Dooren de Jong 1926) to Aminobacter gen. nov. as Aminobacter aminovorans comb. nov. and Aminobacter niigataensis sp. nov.

p.s: Description of Aminobacter aganoensis sp. nov.
Aminobacter aganoensis (a.ga.no.en'sis. M.L. neut. adj. aganoensis, coming from the Agano River, Niigata, Japan)
Aminobacter aganoensis has all of the characteristics which define the genus.
In addition, it has the characteristics described below.
Poor growth occurs in peptone water.
Nitrate is reduced to nitrite weakly.

Acids are produced oxidatively from D-xylose, D-glucose, D-mannose, D-fructose, D-galactose, maltose, sucrose, trehalose, D-sorbitol, D-mannitol, inositol, and glycerol, but are not produced from L-arabinose, lactose, and soluble starch.
Formation of acids from D-glucose, D-mannose, maltose, sucrose, trehalose, D-sorbitol, D-mannitol, and inositol is weak.

L-Arabinose, D-xylose, D-glucose, D-mannose, D-fructose, D-galactose, maltose, sucrose, trehalose, D-sorbitol, D-mannitol, inositol, glycerol, succinic acid, acetic acid, monomethylamine, dimethylamine, trimethylamine, trimethylamine-N-oxide, and TMAH are utilized, but lactose, soluble starch, citric acid, formic acid, ethanol, methanol, formamide, N-methylformamide, DMF, methane, and hydrogen are not utilized.
The type strain is strain TH-3.
Strain TH-3T has all of the characteristics given above for the species.
Its DNA base composition is 63.8 mol% G+C.
This strain was isolated as a TMAH-utilizing bacterium from soil by Urakami et al. (40).
The type strain has been deposited in the Japan Collection of Microorganisms, Institute of Physical and Chemical Research, as strain JCM 7854.
